On 10/12/05, Eugene Kuleshov <eu@...> wrote:
>
>
> Quite interesting t=
hat neither TestNG and JUnit4 does not take into
> account IDE or reporting=
 needs.
>
> It is quite obvious that array-based parameter generator will n=
ot
> scale to large test suites. So, framework should provide some way to
>=
 supply test data lazily.
>
> From other hand if you think of IDE it should=
 be possible to run
> just specific test or only selected test cases. o, it=
 seems that there
> should be some random-acess API, which iteterator just =
does not provide.
>
> Also note that one would be interested to know how ma=
ny test cases
> in the given data provider as well as a readable name for e=
ach test.


I exchanged a few emails with JB about that, and my take on "da=
ta names" is
basically: I don't see the need.

If a test method being fed b=
y a data provider fails, it will clearly say
something like "Expected 42 bu=
t got 41". From that point, it's pretty easy
to trace which data from the d=
ata set caused this error and act on it.

Actually, I would probably not ev=
en care about that myself: I would rerun my
tests, put a breakpoint on any =
assertion thrown and let the IDE show me
exactly where and when the test fa=
ils. Whether this test method was fed data
from a DataProvider or from some=
where else is irrelevant to fix the test.

PS: Cedric, I thouight we alread=
y discussed above points. Did you
> forgot that or my arguments wasn't very=
 covincing?


Not at all, Eugene. In my response to Elliotte, I mentioned t=
hat he wasn't
the first one to make this request and I obviously had you in=
 mind :-)

After thinking about it more, it might actually be completely tr=
ivial for
TestNG to support lazy data providers. I'll take a stab at it and=
 I'll
report here with the results.


--
C=E9dric
